feedback.detailed: The internet is not something you can touch! Hardware is the physical parts like your computer, keyboard, and mouse!
feedback.socraticHint: Can you pick up the internet? Or can you only pick up the computer?

questions.correctAnswerText: Computer parts you can touch

questions.prompt: What does the CPU do?

options.text: It's the computer's brain that thinks and makes things work

feedback.short: Correct! The CPU is like the computer's super-fast brain!
feedback.detailed: Yes! The CPU is the brain of the computer! It thinks super fast and makes everything work - like your brain tells your body what to do!

options.text: It shows pictures on the screen

feedback.short: Not quite! That's the monitor's job! The CPU is the brain.
feedback.detailed: The monitor shows pictures! The CPU is different - it's the brain that thinks and tells all the other parts what to do!
feedback.socraticHint: Which part of your body shows you things - your eyes or your brain?

options.text: It lets you type letters

feedback.short: That's the keyboard! The CPU is the thinking part.
feedback.detailed: The keyboard is for typing! The CPU is like the brain - it thinks and processes all the information!
feedback.socraticHint: What part of your body does the thinking - your hands or your brain?

options.text: It prints on paper

feedback.short: That's the printer! The CPU is the brain that thinks.
feedback.detailed: A printer makes paper copies! The CPU is the brain inside the computer that thinks super fast and runs everything!
feedback.socraticHint: Where is the thinking part - inside the computer or in the printer?

questions.correctAnswerText: It's the computer's brain that thinks and makes things work

questions.prompt: What is software?

options.text: Programs you can't touch that make hardware work

feedback.short: Perfect! Software is like magic spells for hardware!
feedback.detailed: Exactly! Software is programs you can't touch - like games and apps! It tells the hardware (the parts you can touch) what to do!

options.text: The keyboard and mouse

feedback.short: Nope! Keyboard and mouse are hardware! Software is programs.
feedback.detailed: You can touch a keyboard and mouse - those are hardware! Software is the programs like games and apps that you can't touch!
feedback.socraticHint: Can you hold a keyboard? Can you hold a program?

options.text: The computer screen

feedback.short: That's hardware! Software is programs you can't touch.
feedback.detailed: The screen is hardware - you can touch it! Software is programs like Tynker and games that you can't physically touch!
feedback.socraticHint: Can you tap the screen with your finger?

options.text: Soft pillows for your chair

feedback.short: Nice try! But software means computer programs, not soft things!
feedback.detailed: The word sounds like 'soft' but it doesn't mean soft things! Software means programs like games and apps inside the computer!
feedback.socraticHint: What does Tynker have inside - games and programs or pillows?

questions.correctAnswerText: Programs you can't touch that make hardware work

questions.prompt: Which one is an example of system software?

options.text: Windows or macOS - the computer's boss

feedback.short: Yes! Windows and macOS run the whole computer!
feedback.detailed: Correct! Windows and macOS are system software - they're like the boss that runs everything on your computer!

options.text: A video game

feedback.short: Not quite! Games are application software, not system software.
feedback.detailed: Games are application software (programs we use for fun)! System software is the boss program like Windows that runs the computer!
feedback.socraticHint: What starts up first - the game or the computer system?

options.text: Your keyboard

feedback.short: That's hardware! System software is a program that runs the computer.
feedback.detailed: A keyboard is hardware you can touch! System software is a program like Windows that controls the whole computer!
feedback.socraticHint: Can you touch a keyboard? Is that a program?

options.text: A web browser like Chrome

feedback.short: That's application software! System software runs the whole computer.
feedback.detailed: Chrome is application software (a program you use)! System software like Windows is the boss that runs everything!
feedback.socraticHint: What needs to be running before you can open Chrome?

questions.correctAnswerText: Windows or macOS - the computer's boss

questions.prompt: What's the difference between a mouse and a touchpad?

options.text: Mouse moves separately, touchpad uses your finger on laptop

feedback.short: Correct! Mouse is separate, touchpad is built into laptops!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! A mouse is a separate piece you move around, but a touchpad is flat on the laptop where you use your finger!

options.text: They are exactly the same thing

feedback.short: Not quite! They both move the arrow but work differently.
feedback.detailed: They both move the arrow on screen, but a mouse is separate and a touchpad is built into the laptop where you use your finger!
feedback.socraticHint: Do you move a mouse with your whole hand or just touch it with your finger?

options.text: Mouse is for games, touchpad is for typing

feedback.short: Not exactly! Both move the arrow - they're just different shapes.
feedback.detailed: Both mouse and touchpad move the arrow around! The difference is a mouse is separate and a touchpad is flat on your laptop!
feedback.socraticHint: Can you type with either of them, or do you need a keyboard for typing?

options.text: Mouse is software, touchpad is hardware

feedback.short: Both are hardware! They're different in how you use them.
feedback.detailed: Both mouse and touchpad are hardware you can touch! The difference is a mouse is separate and a touchpad is built into the laptop!
feedback.socraticHint: Can you touch both of them with your hand?

questions.correctAnswerText: Mouse moves separately, touchpad uses your finger on laptop

questions.prompt: What is a tab in your web browser?

options.text: A separate window for different web pages

feedback.short: Correct! Tabs let you have many web pages open at once!
feedback.detailed: Yes! Tabs are like pages in a book - you can have many open at the same time in one window!

options.text: A button on your keyboard

feedback.short: Not quite! That's the Tab key. Browser tabs are different!
feedback.detailed: There is a Tab key on your keyboard, but browser tabs are windows inside your web browser for different pages!
feedback.socraticHint: Where do you see tabs - on your keyboard or at the top of your browser?

options.text: A folder on your computer

feedback.short: Nope! Folders store files. Tabs show different web pages!
feedback.detailed: Folders hold files! Tabs are different - they let you look at many different websites at the same time in your browser!
feedback.socraticHint: Do you use tabs when you're browsing the internet or organizing files?

options.text: A type of computer mouse

feedback.short: That's not right! Tabs are parts of your web browser, not mice!
feedback.detailed: A mouse is hardware! Tabs are the separate windows you see at the top of your browser for different web pages!
feedback.socraticHint: Can you touch and hold a tab like you can hold a mouse?

questions.correctAnswerText: A separate window for different web pages

questions.prompt: What's the difference between a file and a folder?

options.text: Folders hold files inside, files are like toys in the toy box

feedback.short: Perfect! Folders are containers, files are the things inside!
feedback.detailed: Exactly! Think of folders as toy boxes that hold things, and files as the toys inside! Folders organize your files!

options.text: They are the same thing

feedback.short: Not quite! Folders hold files - they're different!
feedback.detailed: Folders and files are different! A folder is like a backpack that holds things, and files are like the books inside the backpack!
feedback.socraticHint: Is a toy box the same as the toys inside it?

options.text: Files hold folders inside

feedback.short: It's the opposite! Folders hold files, not the other way around!
feedback.detailed: It's backwards! Folders are the containers, and files go inside folders. Like toys go inside a toy box, not the other way!
feedback.socraticHint: Do books go inside a backpack, or does a backpack go inside books?

options.text: Files are only for pictures, folders are for everything else

feedback.short: Not true! Files can be anything - pictures, games, documents!
feedback.detailed: Files can be pictures, documents, games, and more! Folders are containers that help organize any type of file!
feedback.socraticHint: Can you have different types of toys in one toy box?

questions.correctAnswerText: Folders hold files inside, files are like toys in the toy box

questions.prompt: What does Ctrl+C do on Windows (or Command+C on Mac)?

options.text: Copy - makes a copy of what you selected

feedback.short: Yes! It copies like a copy machine!
feedback.detailed: Correct! Ctrl+C (or Command+C) copies what you picked. It's like using a copy machine - you can paste it somewhere else!

options.text: Cut - removes it and saves it

feedback.short: Not quite! That's Ctrl+X! Ctrl+C is for copying.
feedback.detailed: Ctrl+X cuts! Ctrl+C is different - it COPIES (like taking a photo) without removing the original!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'C' stand for Copy or Cut?

options.text: Close the window

feedback.short: Nope! Ctrl+C copies things. It doesn't close windows!
feedback.detailed: Closing windows is different! Ctrl+C copies what you selected so you can paste it somewhere else!
feedback.socraticHint: What does the 'C' in Ctrl+C remind you of - Copy or Close?

options.text: Clear everything on the screen

feedback.short: Not at all! Ctrl+C makes a copy - it doesn't clear anything!
feedback.detailed: Ctrl+C is safe - it just copies! It doesn't clear or delete anything. Your original stays right where it is!
feedback.socraticHint: When you copy something, does the original disappear or stay?

questions.correctAnswerText: Copy - makes a copy of what you selected

questions.prompt: Why do we learn to type with all our fingers instead of just pointing and pecking?

options.text: It's faster and your fingers learn where the keys are

feedback.short: Exactly! Using all fingers is much faster once you learn!
feedback.detailed: Yes! When each finger has its own keys, you can type super fast without looking! It's like learning to play piano!

options.text: It looks cooler to other people

feedback.short: Not really! It's about being faster and more comfortable!
feedback.detailed: Using all fingers helps YOU type faster and easier! Your fingers remember where keys are, like magic typing!
feedback.socraticHint: Which would help you more - looking cool or getting your work done faster?

options.text: The computer only works that way

feedback.short: Not true! The computer works either way - but all fingers is faster!
feedback.detailed: The computer doesn't care how you type! But using all fingers helps you type faster and without getting tired!
feedback.socraticHint: Does the computer know if you use one finger or ten?

options.text: One finger wears out the keyboard

feedback.short: That's not why! It's because using all fingers is much faster!
feedback.detailed: Keyboards don't wear out from one finger! We use all fingers because it's faster and your hands don't get tired!
feedback.socraticHint: Would it be faster to walk with one leg or run with both?

questions.correctAnswerText: It's faster and your fingers learn where the keys are

questions.prompt: Which fingers should press the space bar?

options.text: Your thumbs - both of them can share!

feedback.short: Perfect! Thumbs are the space bar experts!
feedback.detailed: Yes! Both thumbs can press the space bar! They're like the space bar champions of your hands!

options.text: Your pinky fingers

feedback.short: Not quite! Pinkies press other keys. Thumbs press space!
feedback.detailed: Pinky fingers are for keys like Q, A, Z, and P! Your thumbs are the ones that press the big space bar!
feedback.socraticHint: Which finger is closest to the big space bar?

options.text: Your pointer fingers

feedback.short: Nope! Pointers are for other letters. Thumbs press space!
feedback.detailed: Pointer fingers have lots of keys to press like F, J, and others! Thumbs are perfect for the space bar!
feedback.socraticHint: What's the biggest finger closest to the space bar?

options.text: Any finger you want

feedback.short: Thumbs work best! They're right there near the space bar!
feedback.detailed: While you could use any finger, thumbs are perfect because they rest right above the space bar and don't need to type letters!
feedback.socraticHint: Which fingers don't have letter keys to press?

questions.correctAnswerText: Your thumbs - both of them can share!

questions.prompt: What is an event in coding?

options.text: Something that makes your code start running

feedback.short: Perfect! Events are like magic buttons that start actions!
feedback.detailed: Yes! An event starts your code - like pressing the green flag or clicking a character. It's like saying 'GO!'

options.text: A party for your code

feedback.short: Not quite! Events start actions, they're not parties!
feedback.detailed: Events aren't parties! They're special blocks that tell your code when to start - like clicking or pressing keys!
feedback.socraticHint: What happens when you click the green flag in Tynker?

options.text: A character in your game

feedback.short: Nope! Characters are actors. Events make things happen!
feedback.detailed: Characters are called actors! Events are the things that START the action - like clicking or pressing buttons!
feedback.socraticHint: Is the green flag a character, or does it start your code?

options.text: A special color for blocks

feedback.short: Not exactly! Events are blocks that start actions, not just colors!
feedback.detailed: Event blocks might have a color, but what makes them special is they START your code when something happens!
feedback.socraticHint: What do you do with event blocks - look at their color or use them to start code?

questions.correctAnswerText: Something that makes your code start running

questions.prompt: What does the 'On Start' event do?

options.text: Makes your code run when you press the green flag

feedback.short: Yes! Green flag means GO - your code starts!
feedback.detailed: Exactly! When you click the green flag, any code connected to 'On Start' begins running. It's like starting a race!

options.text: Stops all the code

feedback.short: That's the opposite! 'On Start' STARTS the code, not stops it!
feedback.detailed: 'On Start' makes code begin! The red stop button stops code. Green flag with 'On Start' = GO!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'start' mean begin or end?

options.text: Changes the background

feedback.short: Nope! 'On Start' begins your code - it doesn't change backgrounds!
feedback.detailed: 'On Start' tells when to begin! To change backgrounds, you need different blocks that actually change the scene!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'start' tell WHEN to do something or WHAT to do?

options.text: Only works one time ever

feedback.short: Not true! It runs every time you click the green flag!
feedback.detailed: 'On Start' works every time you press the green flag! Click it again and your code starts again!
feedback.socraticHint: What happens if you press the green flag twice?

questions.correctAnswerText: Makes your code run when you press the green flag

questions.prompt: What does 'When Key Pressed' event do?

options.text: Makes something happen when you press a keyboard key

feedback.short: Correct! Press a key = action happens!
feedback.detailed: Yes! When you press a specific key on your keyboard, the code connected to that event runs! Like controlling a character in a game!

options.text: Only works with mouse clicks

feedback.short: Not quite! This one is for KEYBOARD keys, not mouse!
feedback.detailed: Mouse clicks use different events! 'When Key Pressed' is specifically for pressing keys on your keyboard like arrows or letters!
feedback.socraticHint: Is a keyboard the same as a mouse?

options.text: Types letters on the screen

feedback.short: Nope! It makes CODE run, it doesn't type letters!
feedback.detailed: 'When Key Pressed' starts your code when you press a key! It doesn't type - it triggers actions like moving a character!
feedback.socraticHint: Does this event write words or start actions?

options.text: Turns off the computer

feedback.short: Not at all! It's for controlling your code, not the computer!
feedback.detailed: 'When Key Pressed' is for your Tynker projects! It makes things happen in your code - it doesn't control the computer itself!
feedback.socraticHint: Is this event dangerous or is it just for games and programs?

questions.correctAnswerText: Makes something happen when you press a keyboard key

questions.prompt: Why do we need events in our code?

options.text: To tell the code when to start doing things

feedback.short: Exactly! Events are the 'start signals' for code!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! Without events, code wouldn't know when to run! Events are like start signals that tell code 'Now is the time!'

options.text: To make the code look colorful

feedback.short: Not about colors! Events tell code WHEN to start!
feedback.detailed: Events are about timing, not looks! They tell your code when to start running - like when you click or press a key!
feedback.socraticHint: Does code run because it's pretty or because something triggers it?

options.text: To make the code run slower

feedback.short: Nope! Events start code at the right time, not slow it down!
feedback.detailed: Events don't slow code down! They make code start at the perfect moment - like when you're ready to play!
feedback.socraticHint: Does pressing 'start' on a game slow it down or begin it?

options.text: Code doesn't need events

feedback.short: Wrong! Code needs events to know when to start!
feedback.detailed: Code definitely needs events! Without them, your code wouldn't know when to run. Events are like the green flag - they say GO!
feedback.socraticHint: What happens if you write code but never click the green flag?

questions.correctAnswerText: To tell the code when to start doing things

questions.prompt: What does 'Broadcast' do?

options.text: Sends a message to all actors to tell them to do something

feedback.short: Perfect! It's like shouting 'Ready!' to everyone!
feedback.detailed: Yes! Broadcast sends a message out to all actors, like using a megaphone! Then actors listen and do what they're programmed to do!

options.text: Makes everything on TV

feedback.short: Not TV broadcast! This is a coding message between actors!
feedback.detailed: In coding, 'broadcast' means sending a message to your actors, not making TV shows! It's like actors talking to each other!
feedback.socraticHint: Are we talking about TV or coding messages?

options.text: Deletes all the actors

feedback.short: No way! Broadcast is for sending messages, not deleting!
feedback.detailed: Broadcast is friendly! It sends messages to tell actors what to do next. It doesn't delete anything!
feedback.socraticHint: Does sending someone a message make them disappear?

options.text: Makes sounds louder

feedback.short: Not about volume! Broadcast sends messages between actors!
feedback.detailed: Broadcast doesn't change sound! It's a way for one actor to send a message to other actors in your code!
feedback.socraticHint: Is 'broadcast' about sound levels or sending messages?

questions.correctAnswerText: Sends a message to all actors to tell them to do something

questions.prompt: What does the 'animate' block do?

options.text: Makes your character move or do actions

feedback.short: Correct! It makes characters dance, jump, and move!
feedback.detailed: Yes! The animate block makes your character do cool moves like dancing, waving, or jumping! One click = one action!

options.text: Draws pictures on the screen

feedback.short: Not quite! It makes characters move, not draw pictures!
feedback.detailed: The animate block makes your character do actions! For drawing, you'd use stamp or pen blocks!
feedback.socraticHint: Does animation make something move or create new pictures?

options.text: Changes the background color

feedback.short: Nope! Animate is for character movements, not backgrounds!
feedback.detailed: Animate makes your character move! To change backgrounds, you need different blocks made for backgrounds!
feedback.socraticHint: Does animation affect what characters do or what the background looks like?

options.text: Makes things invisible

feedback.short: That's different! Animate makes characters move and act!
feedback.detailed: Animate is for movements and actions! To make things invisible, you'd use show/hide blocks!
feedback.socraticHint: When something animates, do you see it move or does it disappear?

questions.correctAnswerText: Makes your character move or do actions

questions.prompt: What does the 'forever' block do?

options.text: Repeats the code inside over and over

feedback.short: Perfect! It keeps going like a hamster wheel!
feedback.detailed: Exactly! Forever blocks make the code inside repeat over and over, non-stop! Like a hamster wheel that keeps spinning!

options.text: Runs the code only one time

feedback.short: That's the opposite! Forever means it repeats, not just once!
feedback.detailed: Forever means it keeps going! If you want something once, you don't need the forever block - just connect it to an event!
feedback.socraticHint: What does the word 'forever' mean - once or many times?

options.text: Stops all the code

feedback.short: Nope! Forever keeps code running - it doesn't stop it!
feedback.detailed: Forever is the opposite of stopping! It makes code keep going and going until you press the stop button!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'forever' sound like stopping or continuing?

options.text: Makes the project save automatically

feedback.short: Not about saving! Forever makes code repeat over and over!
feedback.detailed: Forever is about repeating code, not saving! It makes whatever's inside it keep happening again and again!
feedback.socraticHint: Is 'forever' about what code does or about saving files?

questions.correctAnswerText: Repeats the code inside over and over

questions.prompt: What does an 'if-then' block do?

options.text: Checks if something is true, then does an action

feedback.short: Yes! It asks a question and does something if the answer is yes!
feedback.detailed: Exactly! If-then blocks make choices! IF something is true, THEN do the action inside. Like 'IF it's raining, THEN bring an umbrella!'

options.text: Makes things happen at the same time

feedback.short: Not quite! It makes choices based on true or false!
feedback.detailed: If-then doesn't do things at once - it makes a choice! IF something is true, THEN it does the action. If false, it skips it!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'if-then' mean 'do both' or 'check first, then decide'?

options.text: Repeats code forever

feedback.short: That's the forever block! If-then makes decisions!
feedback.detailed: Forever blocks repeat! If-then blocks make choices - they check if something is true and only do the action if it is!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'if' sound like repeating or making a choice?

options.text: Stops the program completely

feedback.short: Nope! It makes smart choices, it doesn't stop everything!
feedback.detailed: If-then blocks make decisions! They check conditions and do actions based on whether something is true or false!
feedback.socraticHint: Does checking 'if' something is true mean stopping or deciding?

questions.correctAnswerText: Checks if something is true, then does an action

questions.prompt: Why would you put an animate block inside a forever block?

options.text: To make the character keep doing the animation over and over

feedback.short: Perfect! Forever makes the animation repeat non-stop!
feedback.detailed: Exactly! Putting animate inside forever makes your character keep dancing or moving continuously! It won't stop until you stop it!

options.text: To make the animation go slower

feedback.short: Not about speed! Forever makes it repeat, not slow down!
feedback.detailed: Forever doesn't change speed - it makes the animation happen again and again! For speed, you'd use wait blocks!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'forever' mean slower or repeating?

options.text: To make two characters animate at once

feedback.short: Not for multiple characters! Forever makes one character repeat!
feedback.detailed: Forever makes the code repeat for that character! For two characters, you'd give each one their own code!
feedback.socraticHint: Does one forever block control one character or many?

options.text: To make the character bigger

feedback.short: Not about size! Forever makes things repeat!
feedback.detailed: Forever makes actions repeat! To change size, you'd need size blocks. Forever just keeps doing the same thing over and over!
feedback.socraticHint: Does repeating something make it bigger or just do it more times?

questions.correctAnswerText: To make the character keep doing the animation over and over

questions.prompt: What is the Character Builder in Tynker?

options.text: A tool to create and customize your own characters

feedback.short: Yes! It lets you make your own special characters!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! Character Builder is like a magic workshop where you create custom characters by picking body parts, colors, and styles!

options.text: A person who builds computers

feedback.short: Not a person! It's a Tynker tool for making characters!
feedback.detailed: Character Builder is a tool inside Tynker! It helps you design your own actors for your projects!
feedback.socraticHint: Is this about a job or a tool in Tynker?

options.text: A block that makes characters move

feedback.short: Not a block! It's a tool for creating characters!
feedback.detailed: Character Builder is where you DESIGN characters! Animation blocks are what make them move after you create them!
feedback.socraticHint: Do you use Character Builder before or after adding code blocks?

options.text: A way to delete characters

feedback.short: Opposite! Character Builder CREATES characters, not deletes them!
feedback.detailed: Character Builder is for making new characters! It helps you design and customize actors for your projects!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'builder' mean create or delete?

questions.correctAnswerText: A tool to create and customize your own characters

questions.prompt: What does the 'stamp' block do?

options.text: Leaves a copy of your character on the screen

feedback.short: Perfect! It's like a rubber stamp - leaves a mark!
feedback.detailed: Yes! The stamp block is like a rubber stamp! It leaves an image of your character wherever it is, creating cool art!

options.text: Makes your character jump

feedback.short: Not for jumping! Stamp leaves copies of your character!
feedback.detailed: Stamp doesn't make movement! It leaves a copy of your character in its current spot, like pressing a rubber stamp!
feedback.socraticHint: Does a rubber stamp make things jump or leave a mark?

options.text: Sends messages to other actors

feedback.short: That's broadcast! Stamp creates art by leaving copies!
feedback.detailed: Broadcasting sends messages! Stamp is for art - it leaves copies of your character on the screen!
feedback.socraticHint: Is stamp about communication or making art?

options.text: Erases everything on screen

feedback.short: That's clear! Stamp ADDS copies - it doesn't erase!
feedback.detailed: Stamp adds to your art by leaving copies! The 'clear' block is what erases everything!
feedback.socraticHint: Does a stamp add marks or remove them?

questions.correctAnswerText: Leaves a copy of your character on the screen

questions.prompt: What do visual effects like 'ghost', 'whirl', and 'pixelate' do?

options.text: Change how your character looks

feedback.short: Yes! They make your character look different and cool!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! Visual effects change your character's appearance - ghost makes it see-through, whirl makes it spin, pixelate makes it blocky!

options.text: Make your character move faster

feedback.short: Not about speed! Effects change how things look!
feedback.detailed: Visual effects change appearance, not speed! They make your character look different - see-through, swirly, or blocky!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'visual' mean how things look or how fast they move?

options.text: Delete your character

feedback.short: They don't delete! They just change how things look!
feedback.detailed: Effects are safe! They just change appearance temporarily. Your character is still there, just looks different!
feedback.socraticHint: If you add a ghost effect, does the character disappear completely?

options.text: Play music and sounds

feedback.short: Not sounds! Visual effects change how things LOOK!
feedback.detailed: Visual effects are for your eyes, not your ears! They change appearance. Sound blocks are different!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'visual' mean what you see or what you hear?

questions.correctAnswerText: Change how your character looks

questions.prompt: What does 'when key pressed' let you do in Street Art?

options.text: Control different effects or actions with keyboard keys

feedback.short: Correct! Each key can trigger different art effects!
feedback.detailed: Yes! You can make different keys do different things - press A for stars, B for effects, arrows to move! It's like keyboard magic!

options.text: Type words on the screen

feedback.short: Not for typing! It triggers actions and effects!
feedback.detailed: When key pressed doesn't type - it triggers CODE! It makes effects happen, characters move, or art appear!
feedback.socraticHint: Is this event for writing words or controlling your art?

options.text: Turn the computer on and off

feedback.short: Not for the computer! It controls your Tynker project!
feedback.detailed: When key pressed works inside Tynker! It controls your project - making effects, moving characters, creating art!
feedback.socraticHint: Does this event control Tynker or the whole computer?

options.text: Save your project automatically

feedback.short: Not for saving! It triggers the actions you program!
feedback.detailed: When key pressed makes YOUR code run! Whatever actions you programmed for that key will happen when you press it!
feedback.socraticHint: Does this event run code you wrote or does it save files?

questions.correctAnswerText: Control different effects or actions with keyboard keys

questions.prompt: What does the 'clear' block do?

options.text: Removes all stamps and art from the screen

feedback.short: Yes! It's like a magic eraser for your art!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! Clear removes all the stamps and art you made, giving you a clean screen to start fresh!

options.text: Makes your character invisible

feedback.short: That's hide! Clear removes stamps, not characters!
feedback.detailed: Hide makes characters invisible! Clear is different - it removes all the stamp marks and art, but your character stays!
feedback.socraticHint: Does clear affect your character or the art you've stamped?

options.text: Makes the screen brighter

feedback.short: Not about brightness! Clear removes stamped art!
feedback.detailed: Clear doesn't change brightness! It removes all the stamps and art you've created, like wiping a whiteboard clean!
feedback.socraticHint: When you clean a whiteboard, does it get brighter or just cleaner?

options.text: Deletes all your code

feedback.short: Don't worry! It only clears art, not your code!
feedback.detailed: Clear is safe! It only removes the visual art on screen. Your code and characters are safe and stay exactly as they are!
feedback.socraticHint: Does clear affect what's drawn on screen or the code you wrote?

questions.correctAnswerText: Removes all stamps and art from the screen

questions.prompt: What does 'go to' block do?

options.text: Makes your character jump to a new location instantly

feedback.short: Correct! It's like teleporting to a new spot!
feedback.detailed: Yes! Go to makes your character teleport instantly to another actor or a specific position - like magic!

options.text: Opens a new web page

feedback.short: Not for web pages! It moves your character in Tynker!
feedback.detailed: Go to is for moving characters in your project! It makes them jump to different positions on the screen!
feedback.socraticHint: Are we controlling a web browser or a character in Tynker?

options.text: Starts playing music

feedback.short: Not for music! Go to moves characters to new positions!
feedback.detailed: Go to is about movement and position! For music, you'd use sound blocks. Go to makes characters teleport!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'go to' sound like making sounds or moving locations?

options.text: Closes the project

feedback.short: It doesn't close anything! It moves your character!
feedback.detailed: Go to moves characters to new spots on screen! It doesn't close or stop anything - just instant movement!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'go to a location' mean closing or moving?

questions.correctAnswerText: Makes your character jump to a new location instantly

questions.prompt: What does 'broadcast' do in a magic show?

options.text: Sends a message to tell all actors to do something

feedback.short: Perfect! It's like the magician's secret signal!
feedback.detailed: Yes! Broadcast sends a message to all actors! When you broadcast 'disappear', any actor listening does their disappear action!

options.text: Makes sounds louder

feedback.short: Not about volume! Broadcast sends messages between actors!
feedback.detailed: Broadcast isn't about sound! It's about communication - sending messages from one actor to other actors in your show!
feedback.socraticHint: Is broadcast about sound levels or sending signals?

options.text: Shows the actor on TV

feedback.short: Not TV! Broadcast sends messages in your Tynker project!
feedback.detailed: In coding, broadcast means sending a message to actors in your project! It's like using walkie-talkies, not TV!
feedback.socraticHint: Are we making TV shows or coordinating actors in code?

options.text: Deletes actors from the show

feedback.short: It doesn't delete! It sends messages to coordinate actions!
feedback.detailed: Broadcast is for communication! It tells actors when to act. What they do depends on their code - might hide, move, or anything!
feedback.socraticHint: Does sending someone a message delete them?

questions.correctAnswerText: Sends a message to tell all actors to do something

questions.prompt: What does 'when I receive' block do?

options.text: Waits for a broadcast message, then runs the code

feedback.short: Yes! It listens for messages like having super ears!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! When I receive waits for a specific broadcast message, then runs its code! It's like waiting to hear your name called!

options.text: Gets mail from the mailbox

feedback.short: Not real mail! It receives broadcast messages in code!
feedback.detailed: When I receive listens for code messages (broadcasts)! It's not about real mail - it's about actors communicating!
feedback.socraticHint: Are we talking about real mail or messages between actors?

options.text: Gives the actor a gift

feedback.short: Not gifts! It receives broadcast signals to start actions!
feedback.detailed: When I receive listens for messages in your code! When it hears the right message, it runs its code - no gifts involved!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'receive' mean getting a physical gift or getting a signal?

options.text: Stops all the code

feedback.short: It doesn't stop! It STARTS code when it gets a message!
feedback.detailed: When I receive starts code, not stops it! When the message arrives, the code connected to it begins running!
feedback.socraticHint: When you receive a start signal, do you stop or begin?

questions.correctAnswerText: Waits for a broadcast message, then runs the code

questions.prompt: What does the 'ask and wait' block do?

options.text: Asks the player a question and waits for their answer

feedback.short: Correct! It asks and waits for you to type!
feedback.detailed: Yes! Ask and wait shows a question to the player, then pauses until they type an answer. Then you can use their answer in your code!

options.text: Makes the actor stop moving forever

feedback.short: Not forever! It just pauses until you type an answer!
feedback.detailed: Ask and wait pauses temporarily while waiting for an answer! Once you answer, the code continues - it's not forever!
feedback.socraticHint: Does waiting for an answer mean stopping forever or pausing temporarily?

options.text: Asks another actor to help

feedback.short: Not other actors! It asks the PLAYER for input!
feedback.detailed: Ask and wait talks to you, the player! It asks you questions and waits for your typed answer!
feedback.socraticHint: Who types the answer - another actor or the person playing?

options.text: Makes everything invisible

feedback.short: Not about visibility! It asks questions and gets answers!
feedback.detailed: Ask and wait is for interaction! It asks the player questions and uses their answers - nothing becomes invisible!
feedback.socraticHint: Does asking a question make things disappear or gather information?

questions.correctAnswerText: Asks the player a question and waits for their answer

questions.prompt: How do broadcast and 'when I receive' work together?

options.text: One actor broadcasts a message, other actors receive it and act

feedback.short: Perfect! It's like walkie-talkies - one talks, others listen!
feedback.detailed: Exactly! One actor broadcasts (sends) a message, and actors with 'when I receive' listen and do their actions! It's teamwork!

options.text: They both do exactly the same thing

feedback.short: They're different! One sends, one receives!
feedback.detailed: Broadcast SENDS messages and 'when I receive' LISTENS for messages! They work together like a phone call - one person talks, another listens!
feedback.socraticHint: Can talking and listening be the same thing?

options.text: They make actors move at the same time

feedback.short: Not just movement! They coordinate any actions through messages!
feedback.detailed: They help actors coordinate! Broadcast sends signals, and 'when I receive' responds - could be movement, sounds, effects, anything!
feedback.socraticHint: Is this about movement specifically or about communication?

options.text: They don't work together at all

feedback.short: They're a team! One sends messages, the other receives them!
feedback.detailed: They're partners! Without broadcast, there's no message. Without 'when I receive', no one listens. They need each other!
feedback.socraticHint: Can you have a phone call with only one phone?

questions.correctAnswerText: One actor broadcasts a message, other actors receive it and act

questions.prompt: What does 'repeat until' block do?

options.text: Keeps repeating code until something becomes true

feedback.short: Yes! It keeps trying until the condition is true!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! Repeat until keeps doing the code inside until something you specify becomes true! Then it stops and moves on!

options.text: Repeats forever and never stops

feedback.short: That's forever! Repeat until stops when condition is true!
feedback.detailed: Forever never stops! Repeat until is different - it keeps going UNTIL something becomes true, then it stops!
feedback.socraticHint: What does 'until' mean - forever or up to a certain point?

options.text: Repeats only one time

feedback.short: It repeats multiple times until condition is true!
feedback.detailed: Repeat until keeps going! It might repeat many times - it stops only when the condition you set becomes true!
feedback.socraticHint: If you practice 'until' you get it right, do you practice once or keep trying?

options.text: Makes everything happen at once

feedback.short: Not all at once! It repeats over and over until done!
feedback.detailed: Repeat until does things one after another in a loop! It keeps repeating until the condition is met - not all at once!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'repeat' mean do many times or do once all together?

questions.correctAnswerText: Keeps repeating code until something becomes true

questions.prompt: What is a clone?

options.text: A copy of an actor that you can create with code

feedback.short: Perfect! Clones are like magic copies!
feedback.detailed: Yes! A clone is a copy of an actor! You can make many stars or enemies by cloning one actor - like making twins with code!

options.text: A type of robot character

feedback.short: Not a robot! Clone means a copy of any actor!
feedback.detailed: Clone isn't a type of character - it's a COPY! You can clone cats, stars, robots, or any actor you want!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'clone' describe what something is or describe making copies?

options.text: A sound effect

feedback.short: Not a sound! Clones are copies of actors!
feedback.detailed: Clones are visual copies of actors, not sounds! They help you make many stars, enemies, or objects appear!
feedback.socraticHint: Can you see a clone on screen or only hear it?

options.text: A type of background

feedback.short: Not backgrounds! Clones are copies of actors!
feedback.detailed: Clones are for actors (characters)! They let you make many copies of one character, like making multiple stars appear!
feedback.socraticHint: Do clones affect the background or the characters?

questions.correctAnswerText: A copy of an actor that you can create with code

questions.prompt: Why should you delete clones when you're done with them?

options.text: Too many clones slow down your game

feedback.short: Yes! Too many clones make the computer work too hard!
feedback.detailed: Exactly! Too many clones make your game run slow like a snail! Delete old clones to keep everything running fast!

options.text: Clones take up space on your desk

feedback.short: Not physical space! They use computer memory!
feedback.detailed: Clones are digital - they don't take desk space! But too many use up computer memory and slow things down!
feedback.socraticHint: Are clones real objects or computer data?

options.text: You only get 3 clones total

feedback.short: You can have many more! But clean up old ones to stay fast!
feedback.detailed: You can make lots of clones! But you should delete old ones you don't need anymore so your game stays fast!
feedback.socraticHint: Is there a tiny limit or is it about keeping things running smoothly?

options.text: Clones are dangerous

feedback.short: Clones are safe! Delete them to keep your game fast, not for safety!
feedback.detailed: Clones aren't dangerous! We delete old ones to keep the game running smoothly. Too many clones just slow things down!
feedback.socraticHint: Are clones harmful or just potentially numerous?

questions.correctAnswerText: Too many clones slow down your game

questions.prompt: What do variables help you do in a game?

options.text: Keep track of numbers like score or lives

feedback.short: Perfect! Variables are like magic boxes that remember numbers!
feedback.detailed: Yes! Variables remember important numbers like your score, how many lives you have, or time left! They're like memory boxes!

options.text: Make characters move faster

feedback.short: Not about speed! Variables remember numbers like scores!
feedback.detailed: Variables don't change speed - they REMEMBER numbers! Like keeping track of your score or counting stars collected!
feedback.socraticHint: Does a scoreboard make you faster or just keep track of points?

options.text: Change the background color

feedback.short: Not for backgrounds! Variables store and remember numbers!
feedback.detailed: Variables are for remembering numbers! For backgrounds, you'd use different blocks. Variables track scores, lives, time!
feedback.socraticHint: Is a variable a visual thing or a memory thing?

options.text: Delete all clones

feedback.short: Variables don't delete! They remember numbers for you!
feedback.detailed: Variables store numbers - they don't delete things! Delete clone blocks delete clones. Variables just remember numbers!
feedback.socraticHint: Does keeping score delete things or just count them?

questions.correctAnswerText: Keep track of numbers like score or lives

questions.prompt: What does 'when occurs' block do?

options.text: Runs code when something specific happens, like touching another actor

feedback.short: Yes! It's like a smart alarm that watches for changes!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! When occurs watches for specific things to happen - like when score changes or when actors touch! Then it runs code!

options.text: Happens only one time at the start

feedback.short: Not just once! It watches and runs whenever the condition is true!
feedback.detailed: When occurs keeps watching! Every time the condition becomes true (like touching), it runs the code again!
feedback.socraticHint: If you touch something multiple times, does it only notice once?

options.text: Makes random things happen

feedback.short: Not random! It watches for SPECIFIC things to happen!
feedback.detailed: When occurs isn't random! It watches for specific conditions you choose - like touching, scoring, or reaching a number!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'when occurs' mean random or when a specific condition is met?

options.text: Stops all the code forever

feedback.short: It doesn't stop! It STARTS code when conditions are met!
feedback.detailed: When occurs triggers code to run! It doesn't stop things - it's an event that makes specific code start!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'when' something happens mean stop or start an action?

questions.correctAnswerText: Runs code when something specific happens, like touching another actor

questions.prompt: What does 'pick random' do?

options.text: Chooses a surprise number between two numbers you pick

feedback.short: Yes! It's like rolling dice - you get a surprise number!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! Pick random chooses a surprise number between your min and max! Great for making stars appear in different spots!

options.text: Always picks the same number

feedback.short: Opposite! Random means different each time!
feedback.detailed: Random means surprise! It picks different numbers each time, like rolling dice. That's what makes games fun and unpredictable!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'random' mean the same every time or different?

options.text: Picks the biggest number possible

feedback.short: Not always biggest! It picks ANY number in the range!
feedback.detailed: Pick random can choose any number between your min and max! Could be big, small, or in the middle - it's a surprise!
feedback.socraticHint: If you roll dice, do you always get the biggest number?

options.text: Deletes random actors

feedback.short: It doesn't delete! It picks surprise numbers!
feedback.detailed: Pick random is for numbers! It helps you create variety by choosing random positions, sizes, or values - nothing gets deleted!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'pick' mean delete or choose?

questions.correctAnswerText: Chooses a surprise number between two numbers you pick

questions.prompt: What does 'debugging' mean?

options.text: Finding and fixing problems in your code

feedback.short: Yes! Debugging is being a code detective!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! Debugging means finding bugs (mistakes) in your code and fixing them! Like being a detective who solves code mysteries!

options.text: Getting rid of real bugs and insects

feedback.short: Not real bugs! Code bugs are mistakes in programs!
feedback.detailed: The word comes from a real moth Grace Hopper found! But now 'debugging' means fixing code mistakes, not catching bugs!
feedback.socraticHint: Are we talking about insects or code problems?

options.text: Making your code more colorful

feedback.short: Not about colors! Debugging means finding and fixing mistakes!
feedback.detailed: Debugging is about fixing problems so your code works correctly! Colors might be pretty, but debugging is about function!
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'bug' refer to mistakes or decorations?

options.text: Deleting all your code to start over

feedback.short: Don't delete everything! Debugging means FIXING problems!
feedback.detailed: Debugging is about finding what's wrong and fixing just that part! You keep your good code and only fix the bugs!
feedback.socraticHint: If your toy breaks, do you fix it or throw away all your toys?

questions.correctAnswerText: Finding and fixing problems in your code

questions.prompt: Your code isn't working when you click the green flag. What should you check first?

options.text: Check if you have an 'On Start' event block connected

feedback.short: Yes! No event = no action!
feedback.detailed: Perfect detective work! Code needs an event block to start! 'On Start' tells the code to run when you click the green flag!

options.text: Delete all your code immediately

feedback.short: Don't delete! Check if blocks are connected first!
feedback.detailed: Never delete everything! First check if your blocks are connected to an event. Often the code is good, just not connected!
feedback.socraticHint: Should you throw away a toy or first check if the batteries are in?

options.text: Change all the colors

feedback.short: Colors aren't the problem! Check your event blocks!
feedback.detailed: Colors don't affect how code works! If code isn't starting, check if you have an event block like 'On Start' connected!
feedback.socraticHint: Does changing colors make code run or just look different?

options.text: Add more actors to the stage

feedback.short: More actors won't help! Check if your code has an event!
feedback.detailed: Adding actors won't fix it! The problem is your code isn't starting. Make sure it has an 'On Start' event block!
feedback.socraticHint: If a car won't start, does adding more cars help?

questions.correctAnswerText: Check if you have an 'On Start' event block connected

questions.prompt: Too many clones appeared and your game is slow! What should you do?

options.text: Add 'delete this clone' when you're done with each clone

feedback.short: Perfect! Clean up old clones to keep games fast!
feedback.detailed: Great debugging! Deleting clones when you're done with them keeps your game running fast. Like cleaning up toys!

options.text: Make even more clones to fix it

feedback.short: That makes it worse! Delete old clones instead!
feedback.detailed: More clones make it slower! The solution is to delete clones you don't need anymore with 'delete this clone' block!
feedback.socraticHint: If your room is too messy, does adding more toys help?

options.text: Change the background color

feedback.short: Background won't help! Delete unused clones!
feedback.detailed: Background color doesn't affect speed! Too many clones slow things down - delete old ones with 'delete this clone'!
feedback.socraticHint: Does changing wallpaper clean up a messy room?

options.text: Hide all the clones

feedback.short: Hiding doesn't help! You need to DELETE them!
feedback.detailed: Hiding clones still keeps them in memory! Use 'delete this clone' to actually remove them and speed things up!
feedback.socraticHint: If toys are making a room crowded, does hiding them create more space?

questions.correctAnswerText: Add 'delete this clone' when you're done with each clone

questions.prompt: Why is debugging an important skill?

options.text: Everyone makes mistakes, and debugging helps you fix them

feedback.short: Yes! Even expert coders debug - mistakes help us learn!
feedback.detailed: Perfect! Every programmer finds bugs in their code! Debugging helps you fix problems and learn from mistakes. It's a superpower!

options.text: So you never make any mistakes

feedback.short: We all make mistakes! Debugging helps us FIX them!
feedback.detailed: Making mistakes is normal and OK! Debugging is about finding and fixing bugs when they happen. That's how we learn!
feedback.socraticHint: Do professional programmers never have bugs or do they just know how to fix them?

options.text: Only beginners need to debug

feedback.short: Even experts debug! Everyone's code has bugs sometimes!
feedback.detailed: Debugging is for everyone! Even professional programmers debug every day. It's a key skill at every level!
feedback.socraticHint: Do professional athletes never make mistakes or do they practice fixing them?

options.text: To make your code look prettier

feedback.short: Not about looks! Debugging makes code WORK correctly!
feedback.detailed: Debugging is about function, not appearance! It's finding and fixing problems so your code does what you want!
feedback.socraticHint: Is debugging about how code looks or how it works?

questions.correctAnswerText: Everyone makes mistakes, and debugging helps you fix them

questions.prompt: What should you do when you find a bug in your code?

options.text: Stay calm, test one thing at a time, and fix it step by step

feedback.short: Perfect approach! You're a debugging superstar!
feedback.detailed: Exactly! Good debugging means: Look at the problem, think about why, test one change, fix it, celebrate! You're doing great!

options.text: Give up and start a new project

feedback.short: Don't give up! Bugs are puzzles you can solve!
feedback.detailed: Every coder faces bugs! They're not scary - they're puzzles! Take your time, test things, and you'll fix it! You can do it!
feedback.socraticHint: Do you throw away a puzzle if it's hard, or keep trying?

options.text: Delete everything and cry

feedback.short: Bugs are normal! Stay positive and fix them step by step!
feedback.detailed: Finding bugs is part of coding! They help us learn! Take a breath, look at the problem calmly, and fix it one step at a time!
feedback.socraticHint: When a toy breaks, do you throw it away or try to fix it?

options.text: Ignore it and hope it goes away

feedback.short: Bugs don't disappear! But you can fix them!
feedback.detailed: Bugs stay until you fix them! Good news - you have the power to fix bugs! Look at them, test solutions, and solve them!
feedback.socraticHint: If your bike has a flat tire, does ignoring it fix it?

questions.correctAnswerText: Stay calm, test one thing at a time, and fix it step by step

## Assessment Guidelines
- Each question is worth 1 point
- Total possible score: 60 points
- Recommended passing score: 42 points (70%)
- **Excellent (54-60 points, 90-100%):** Demonstrates comprehensive understanding of social impact mobile development and SDG alignment
- **Proficient (48-53 points, 80-89%):** Shows solid grasp of key concepts with minor gaps in application
- **Developing (42-47 points, 70-79%):** Basic understanding with some areas needing reinforcement
- **Beginning (<42 points, <70%):** Significant gaps in understanding requiring additional instruction
Throughout the assessment, students should demonstrate understanding of how mobile technology can advance:
- **SDG 3 (Good Health and Well-being):** Mental health apps, crisis intervention, healthcare access
- **SDG 10 (Reduced Inequalities):** Accessibility design, privacy for vulnerable users, inclusive technology
- **SDG 11 (Sustainable Cities):** Location services, environmental data, community features
- **SDG 13 (Climate Action):** Environmental monitoring, data visualization, community engagement
- **SDG 16 (Peace, Justice, Strong Institutions):** Privacy protection, crisis intervention, ethical design
1. **Pre-Assessment:** Use selected questions to gauge prior knowledge of social impact principles
2. **Formative Assessment:** Use concept-specific questions during lessons to check understanding
3. **Summative Assessment:** Use full set for comprehensive evaluation of course learning objectives
4. **Review Tool:** Use incorrectly answered questions for targeted review of social impact concepts
5. **Portfolio Development:** Encourage students to connect MCQ concepts to their project work
---

options.text: Works offline and processes data locally for better privacy

feedback.short: Correct! On-device AI runs without internet and keeps data on the device.
feedback.detailed: On-device AI processes data locally, which means it works without internet (offline) and never sends user data to external servers, providing better privacy and faster response times (<100ms).

options.text: Provides more accurate results than cloud AI

feedback.short: Not quite.
feedback.detailed: Cloud AI typically provides more accurate results due to access to larger, more advanced models. On-device AI's main advantages are speed, privacy, and offline capability.
feedback.socraticHint: Think about what happens when you have no internet connection. Which type of AI can still work?

options.text: Costs less money to use than cloud services

feedback.short: Not the primary advantage.
feedback.detailed: While on-device AI is free after integration, the primary advantage is privacy and offline capability. Cost savings are a benefit but not the defining characteristic.
feedback.socraticHint: What happens to your personal photos when on-device AI analyzes them versus cloud AI?

options.text: Supports more languages than cloud-based AI

feedback.short: Not accurate.
feedback.detailed: Cloud-based AI typically supports more languages and features because it has access to larger models and infrastructure. On-device AI has limited pre-trained capabilities.
feedback.socraticHint: Which type of AI has access to Google's massive servers and latest models?

questions.prompt: What is the primary advantage of on-device AI compared to cloud-based AI?
questions.correctAnswerText: Works offline and processes data locally for better privacy

options.text: ML Kit Text Recognition

feedback.short: Correct! ML Kit OCR runs on-device, works offline, and keeps data private.
feedback.detailed: ML Kit Text Recognition is the perfect choice for privacy-focused OCR because it runs entirely on-device (no internet needed), processes images in under 100ms, and never sends user data to servers.

options.text: Gemini API with vision capabilities

feedback.short: Not ideal for this use case.
feedback.detailed: Gemini requires internet and sends images to Google's servers for processing, which violates the privacy and offline requirements. It's better for complex analysis that ML Kit can't handle.
feedback.socraticHint: Does Gemini work without internet? Where does it process images?

options.text: Vertex AI with custom OCR model

feedback.short: Overengineered solution.
feedback.detailed: Vertex AI requires cloud connectivity and is meant for custom models when standard solutions don't work. ML Kit already provides excellent OCR capabilities without the complexity.
feedback.socraticHint: Why build a custom solution when a free, pre-built on-device option exists?

options.text: Google Translate API

feedback.short: Wrong tool.
feedback.detailed: Google Translate API is for translation, not text extraction (OCR). You need ML Kit Text Recognition to extract text from images first, then optionally translate it.
feedback.socraticHint: What does OCR do? Does translation involve reading text from images?

questions.prompt: Which Google AI service would be BEST for building a privacy-focused feature that extracts text from images offline?
questions.correctAnswerText: ML Kit Text Recognition

options.text: ML Kit: <100ms, Gemini: 2-3 seconds

feedback.short: Correct! On-device processing is much faster than cloud-based AI.
feedback.detailed: ML Kit runs locally and processes images in under 100 milliseconds with no network latency. Gemini requires sending images to servers, AI processing, and network round-trip, taking 2-3 seconds total.

options.text: ML Kit: 2-3 seconds, Gemini: <100ms

feedback.short: You have it backwards.
feedback.detailed: On-device AI (ML Kit) is faster than cloud AI (Gemini) because there's no network latency. ML Kit processes locally in <100ms while Gemini takes 2-3 seconds due to network communication.
feedback.socraticHint: Which is faster: processing on your phone or sending data across the internet to a server and back?

options.text: Both take approximately the same time (1-2 seconds)

feedback.short: Not accurate.
feedback.detailed: There's a significant difference in response times. On-device processing (ML Kit) is nearly instantaneous (<100ms) while cloud-based processing (Gemini) takes 2-3 seconds due to network overhead.
feedback.socraticHint: Think about the difference between opening a photo on your phone versus downloading it from the internet.

options.text: Response time varies based on internet speed only

feedback.short: Incomplete understanding.
feedback.detailed: While internet speed affects Gemini's response time, ML Kit doesn't use the internet at all, so it's unaffected by network conditions. The key difference is on-device versus cloud processing, not just bandwidth.
feedback.socraticHint: Can ML Kit work in airplane mode? What does that tell you about its internet dependency?

questions.prompt: What is the typical response time for ML Kit image labeling compared to Gemini's multimodal analysis?
questions.correctAnswerText: ML Kit: <100ms, Gemini: 2-3 seconds

options.text: ML Kit provides instant feedback while Gemini offers deeper analysis asynchronously

feedback.short: Correct! This hybrid approach combines speed and depth.
feedback.detailed: Using ML Kit first gives users immediate visual feedback (<100ms), then Gemini provides detailed contextual understanding (2-3s later). This creates a smooth UX where users see something instantly and get deeper insights shortly after.

options.text: To make the app more expensive and complex

feedback.short: That's not a benefit.
feedback.detailed: Using both services intelligently actually improves user experience and can reduce costs. ML Kit (free) handles quick tasks, and Gemini (paid) only runs when deeper analysis is needed.
feedback.socraticHint: Would developers intentionally make their apps more expensive for no reason?

options.text: ML Kit doesn't work well, so Gemini is a backup

feedback.short: Not accurate.
feedback.detailed: ML Kit works very well for standard tasks like object detection and labeling. The hybrid approach uses each service for what it does best: ML Kit for speed and privacy, Gemini for complex reasoning and context.
feedback.socraticHint: If ML Kit didn't work well, why would Google offer it as a solution?

options.text: They both give identical results, so it's just for redundancy

feedback.short: They serve different purposes.
feedback.detailed: ML Kit and Gemini provide different types of analysis. ML Kit gives labels and confidence scores ('Dog, 95%'), while Gemini provides contextual understanding ('A happy golden retriever playing fetch'). They complement each other.
feedback.socraticHint: Would '95% confidence: Dog' and 'A golden retriever enjoying playtime in the park' be considered identical results?

questions.prompt: Why might an app use BOTH ML Kit and Gemini for image analysis instead of choosing one?
questions.correctAnswerText: ML Kit provides instant feedback while Gemini offers deeper analysis asynchronously

options.text: In a .env file and loaded through environment variables, NEVER in source code

feedback.short: Correct! API keys should be in .env files and excluded from version control.
feedback.detailed: Store API keys in .env files (and add .env to .gitignore) so they're never committed to GitHub. Access them via environment variables like EXPO_PUBLIC_GEMINI_API_KEY. For production, use a backend proxy to keep keys truly secure.

options.text: Directly in the component code as a string constant

feedback.short: Extremely insecure!
feedback.detailed: Never hardcode API keys in source code. They'll be visible in your repository and app bundle, allowing anyone to steal and abuse them, resulting in unexpected charges and security breaches.
feedback.socraticHint: What happens when you commit code with an API key to a public GitHub repository?

options.text: In AsyncStorage for secure local storage

feedback.short: Not the right approach.
feedback.detailed: AsyncStorage is for user data, not sensitive configuration. API keys should be in environment variables during development and on a backend server for production. AsyncStorage doesn't prevent key extraction from the app bundle.
feedback.socraticHint: Can someone with access to your app's files extract data from AsyncStorage?

options.text: It doesn't matter where you store it, as long as it works

feedback.short: Security matters greatly!
feedback.detailed: API key security is critical. Exposed keys can be stolen and used to rack up thousands of dollars in charges on your account. Always use environment variables and backend proxies for production apps.
feedback.socraticHint: Would you write your bank password directly in your code and push it to GitHub?

questions.prompt: Where should the Gemini API key be stored in a React Native app?
questions.correctAnswerText: In a .env file and loaded through environment variables, NEVER in source code

options.text: Flash is 10x cheaper and faster, Pro has better reasoning for complex tasks

feedback.short: Correct! Flash is optimized for speed and cost, Pro for quality.
feedback.detailed: Gemini 1.5 Flash is designed for most use cases with fast responses and low cost ($0.075 per 1M tokens). Pro is more expensive ($1.25 per 1M tokens) but provides superior reasoning for complex queries that require deep analysis.

options.text: Flash only works with text, Pro supports images

feedback.short: Both support multimodal input.
feedback.detailed: Both Gemini 1.5 Flash and Pro support multimodal input (text + images). The difference is in cost, speed, and reasoning capability, not input types.
feedback.socraticHint: Look at the lesson code examples. Do any use Flash with images?

options.text: Pro is the free tier, Flash requires payment

feedback.short: You have it backwards.
feedback.detailed: Both models have free tiers, but Flash has higher limits (15 RPM, 1M tokens/day) compared to Pro (2 RPM, 50K tokens/day). After free tier, Flash is significantly cheaper.
feedback.socraticHint: Which model name suggests it's faster and lighter?

options.text: They are identical, just different names for the same model

feedback.short: They're different models.
feedback.detailed: Flash and Pro are distinct models with different architectures, capabilities, and pricing. Flash is optimized for speed/cost (most use cases), while Pro excels at complex reasoning tasks.
feedback.socraticHint: Why would Google offer two models if they were identical?

questions.prompt: What is the primary difference between gemini-1.5-flash and gemini-1.5-pro?
questions.correctAnswerText: Flash is 10x cheaper and faster, Pro has better reasoning for complex tasks

options.text: Streaming displays words as they're generated, reducing perceived wait time

feedback.short: Correct! Streaming improves user experience with real-time feedback.
feedback.detailed: Streaming responses appear word-by-word as the AI generates them, making the interaction feel more natural and responsive. Users see progress immediately instead of waiting 2-3 seconds for a complete response.

options.text: Streaming is faster and returns results in half the time

feedback.short: Not about total time.
feedback.detailed: Streaming doesn't reduce total generation time. It provides the same content in the same amount of time, but users perceive it as faster because they see progress immediately rather than waiting for completion.
feedback.socraticHint: Does typing a sentence one letter at a time make it finish faster than typing it all at once?

options.text: Streaming costs less money per request

feedback.short: Cost is the same.
feedback.detailed: Streaming and non-streaming requests cost the same based on token usage. The choice is about user experience (real-time updates) not cost optimization.
feedback.socraticHint: Does the API charge differently based on how you receive the same data?

options.text: Regular generateContent() doesn't work for conversations

feedback.short: Both work for conversations.
feedback.detailed: Both methods work with chat sessions and conversation history. Streaming is purely about delivery format (word-by-word vs all-at-once), not functionality differences.
feedback.socraticHint: Can you maintain conversation context without streaming?

questions.prompt: Why use generateContentStream() instead of generateContent() for chatbot responses?
questions.correctAnswerText: Streaming displays words as they're generated, reducing perceived wait time

options.text: The message and full conversation history are sent to Gemini for context-aware response

feedback.short: Correct! Chat sessions maintain conversation context automatically.
feedback.detailed: When using startChat(), Gemini keeps track of all previous messages. Each sendMessage() call includes the entire conversation history so the AI can provide context-aware responses that reference earlier exchanges.

options.text: Only the current message is sent, previous messages are ignored

feedback.short: That would lose context.
feedback.detailed: Sending only the current message would make the AI forget everything previously discussed. Chat sessions explicitly maintain history to enable contextual, multi-turn conversations.
feedback.socraticHint: How could the AI remember your previous questions if it only sees the latest message?

options.text: Messages are stored in AsyncStorage and retrieved each time

feedback.short: Not how it works.
feedback.detailed: Chat history is maintained in memory by the Gemini SDK, not in AsyncStorage. The SDK sends the conversation history with each request. AsyncStorage would be for persistence across app restarts, which isn't automatic.
feedback.socraticHint: What happens to chat history when you close and reopen the app?

options.text: The AI generates a response without any network communication

feedback.short: Gemini requires network.
feedback.detailed: Gemini is a cloud-based API that requires internet connectivity. Each sendMessage() makes a network request to Google's servers with the conversation context and receives a generated response.
feedback.socraticHint: Is Gemini on-device or cloud-based AI?

questions.prompt: What happens when you call chat.sendMessage() in a Gemini chat session?
questions.correctAnswerText: The message and full conversation history are sent to Gemini for context-aware response

options.text: Rate limit exceeded - implement exponential backoff and retry after waiting

feedback.short: Correct! 429 means too many requests, retry with delays.
feedback.detailed: Error 429 indicates rate limit exceeded (free tier: 15 requests/minute). Handle by implementing exponential backoff: wait 1s, then 2s, then 4s before retrying. Also consider caching to reduce request frequency.

options.text: Invalid API key - check the .env file configuration

feedback.short: Wrong error code.
feedback.detailed: Invalid API key returns error 400 or 401, not 429. Error 429 specifically indicates rate limiting - too many requests in a short time period.
feedback.socraticHint: What does the number 429 mean in HTTP status codes?

options.text: Server is down - switch to ML Kit immediately

feedback.short: Not a server outage.
feedback.detailed: Server errors use 500-series codes. 429 means the API is working but you've exceeded usage limits. Wait and retry rather than switching to a completely different service.
feedback.socraticHint: If the server was down, would it be able to tell you that you're making too many requests?

options.text: Response is too large - reduce maxOutputTokens

feedback.short: Different issue.
feedback.detailed: Large responses might cause timeout or token limit errors, but 429 specifically means rate limiting. You're making requests too frequently, not that responses are too large.
feedback.socraticHint: Does error 429 mention anything about response size or request frequency?

questions.prompt: A user's Gemini API call fails with a 429 error. What does this mean and how should it be handled?
questions.correctAnswerText: Rate limit exceeded - implement exponential backoff and retry after waiting

options.text: For factual Q&A, classification, and tasks requiring consistent, deterministic outputs

feedback.short: Correct! Low temperature produces consistent, factual responses.
feedback.detailed: Temperature 0.0-0.3 makes responses more deterministic and factual. Perfect for tasks like answering questions, classification, translation, or any scenario where you need predictable, accurate outputs rather than creativity.

options.text: For creative writing, storytelling, and brainstorming ideas

feedback.short: That requires high temperature.
feedback.detailed: Creative tasks need HIGH temperature (0.8-1.5) to generate diverse, imaginative responses. Low temperature would produce repetitive, predictable output unsuitable for creative work.
feedback.socraticHint: Would a story be more interesting if it was the same every time or varied with creative ideas?

options.text: When you want the AI to generate different responses each time

feedback.short: Opposite of what low temperature does.
feedback.detailed: Low temperature makes responses MORE similar across repeated requests. For varied responses, use higher temperature (0.8+) which introduces more randomness.
feedback.socraticHint: Does 'deterministic' mean same or different results each time?

options.text: Temperature doesn't affect output quality, only response time

feedback.short: Temperature affects output quality.
feedback.detailed: Temperature controls randomness in token selection, significantly affecting output quality and creativity. It doesn't impact response time, which is determined by model size and token count.
feedback.socraticHint: Why would the API offer a temperature parameter if it didn't change the output?

questions.prompt: When should you use a LOW temperature (0.0-0.3) for Gemini requests?
questions.correctAnswerText: For factual Q&A, classification, and tasks requiring consistent, deterministic outputs

options.text: AI that can process both text and images together

feedback.short: Correct! Multimodal means multiple input types (modalities) like text + images.
feedback.detailed: Gemini 1.5 is multimodal because it can process text and images simultaneously, understanding context across both modalities. This enables features like visual question answering and image-based conversations.

options.text: AI that works in multiple programming languages

feedback.short: Not quite.
feedback.detailed: Multimodal refers to input types (text, images, audio), not programming languages. Gemini can understand different data formats, not code languages.
feedback.socraticHint: Think about the types of data (text vs images) rather than programming concepts.

options.text: AI that can run on multiple devices simultaneously

feedback.short: Not accurate.
feedback.detailed: Multimodal describes the ability to process different input types (text, images), not deployment across devices. That would be 'distributed' or 'multi-platform'.
feedback.socraticHint: What does 'modal' mean in this context - device types or data types?

options.text: AI that provides multiple different answer formats

feedback.short: That's not the definition.
feedback.detailed: Multimodal refers to input capabilities (text + images), not output formats. While Gemini can generate various outputs, multimodal specifically means accepting multiple input types.
feedback.socraticHint: Focus on what goes INTO the AI, not what comes OUT.

questions.prompt: What does 'multimodal AI' mean in the context of Gemini 1.5?
questions.correctAnswerText: AI that can process both text and images together

options.text: Base64 encodes binary image data as text that can be included in JSON

feedback.short: Correct! Base64 converts binary data to ASCII text for safe JSON transmission.
feedback.detailed: Images are binary files, but JSON (used for API requests) only supports text. Base64 encoding converts binary image data into a text representation that can be safely embedded in JSON payloads.

options.text: Base64 compresses images to save bandwidth

feedback.short: Not the primary reason.
feedback.detailed: Base64 actually increases file size by about 33%. It's used for encoding binary data as text, not compression. Always compress images BEFORE base64 encoding.
feedback.socraticHint: Does converting numbers to letters make data smaller or larger?

options.text: Gemini can only process images in base64 format

feedback.short: Not technically accurate.
feedback.detailed: Gemini processes images internally as binary data. Base64 is used for API transmission (JSON format requirement), not for Gemini's internal processing.
feedback.socraticHint: Is base64 for the API transport layer or Gemini's internal processing?

options.text: Base64 removes metadata that violates privacy

feedback.short: Wrong purpose.
feedback.detailed: Base64 encoding preserves all image data including metadata. It's purely for format conversion (binary to text), not privacy or metadata removal.
feedback.socraticHint: Does encoding data in a different format remove information from it?

questions.prompt: Why must images be converted to base64 format before sending to Gemini?
questions.correctAnswerText: Base64 encodes binary image data as text that can be included in JSON

options.text: The request will fail with an error - compress the image first

feedback.short: Correct! Always compress images to <20MB before sending.
feedback.detailed: Gemini's API enforces a 20MB limit per image. Requests with larger images will fail with a 400 error. Use expo-image-manipulator to compress images to <1MB at 70-80% quality before base64 encoding.

options.text: Gemini will automatically compress it server-side

feedback.short: No automatic compression.
feedback.detailed: Gemini doesn't auto-compress images. The request will be rejected before processing begins. You must compress images client-side using tools like expo-image-manipulator.
feedback.socraticHint: Would an API waste resources processing invalid requests or reject them immediately?

options.text: It works but costs more due to extra processing

feedback.short: The request won't even process.
feedback.detailed: Oversized images are rejected before any processing or billing occurs. The 20MB limit is enforced at the API gateway level, so you won't be charged for failed requests.
feedback.socraticHint: Do APIs typically process invalid inputs and charge you, or reject them upfront?

options.text: Only the first 20MB will be analyzed

feedback.short: Images can't be partially processed.
feedback.detailed: Images are atomic units - you can't send 'part' of an image. The entire request fails if the image exceeds 20MB. Compress before sending, don't rely on truncation.
feedback.socraticHint: Can you view half of a corrupt image file?

questions.prompt: What happens if you send a 25MB image to Gemini (which has a 20MB limit)?
questions.correctAnswerText: The request will fail with an error - compress the image first

options.text: iPhone captures HEIC images by default - convert to JPEG first
